questions.text: You visit a new born near your house & identify that the child has CTEV. When will you advice the baby's parents to seek consult to put a cast?
questions.solution:
Ideally, the treatment of a child with CTEV, should be started as early as possible. In the first 2 weeks of life, the mother is advised to do gentle corrective manipulation of the foot. From 2 weeks onwards the child should be under the care of an orthopaedic surgeon, who will put weekly corrective casts. The technique we currently use for correcting CTEV is the Ponseti technique.

  • Ponsetti's philosophy: This philosophy is based on better understanding of the pathoanatomy of the deformed foot. According to Ponsetti, the calcaneo-cuboid-navicular complex is internally rotated (adducted) under the plantarflexed talus, Hence, the deformity can be corrected by bringing the complex back under the talus by gradually stretching the tight structures. This is done by putting thumb pressure over the talus head (and not over calcaneo-cuboid joint as in Kite's method). By doing this, the calcaneocuboid-navicular complex is externally rotated under the talar head.

questions.text: If the outer sheath and nerve fibre is intact and the inner axon are damaged, it is known as
questions.solution:
Seddon's classification: Seddon classifies nerve injuries into three types:

  1. Neurapraxia;
  2. Axonotmesis; and
  3. Neurotmesis.

Neurapraxia: It is a physiological disruption of conduction in the nerve fibre. No structural changes occur. Recovery occurs spontaneously within a few weeks, and is complete.

Axonotmesis: The axons are damaged but atleast one of the outer coverings of nerve intact. Wallerian degeneration occurs. Recovery may occur spontaneously but may take many months. Complete recovery may not occur.

Neurotmesis: The structure of a nerve is damaged by actual cutting or scarring of a segment. Wallerian degeneration occurs. Spontaneous recovery is not possible, and nerve repair is required.

questions.text:
Which of the following tests are not commonly used in osteoporosis:
A. DEXA
B. Bone scan
C. Quantitative CT
D. Chemical analysis
E. X-ray
questions.solution:
Usually x ray and DEXA scan are used to evaluate osteoporosis.

Bone scan, quantitative CT, and chemical analysis are not commonly used for osteoporosis.

DEXA SCAN

Dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan

Based on a similar principle as SPA (SINGLE PHOTON ABSORPTIOMETRY), this test measures the quantity of mineral salts in the bone. Generally, lumbar spine and hip NOF measurements are taken but wrist and ankle can also be evaluated.

The test grades the disease based upon a T-score and a Z-score.

T-score-Measures BMD at its highest level and compares to reference value (30-year-old of same sex, ethnicity).

Z-score-Compares BMD with a subject of same age and sex.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has given the diagnostic criteria for osteoporosis based upon the BMD T score measured on a DEXA scan whereby osteoporosis is defined as a T-score of greater than or equal to 2.5 standard deviations below normal.

questions.text: 35 year old male presents with knee pain. His x ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is: A. Patellar fracture

  • Patellar fractures are common injuries that can result from direct trauma or falls, especially in active individuals. The presentation of knee pain in a young adult, combined with the X-ray findings, suggests a fracture of the patella.
  • The other options, while possible causes of knee pain, do not specifically align with the common presentation of a patellar fracture:
    • B. Rheumatoid arthritis: This condition typically presents with joint inflammation and pain but is less likely to cause acute knee pain with a specific fracture pattern on X-ray.
    • C. Hemophilic arthropathy: This condition is associated with bleeding into the joints, leading to chronic pain and swelling, but it would not typically present with an acute fracture.
    • D. Tibial condylar fracture: While this is a possibility, the specific mention of knee pain and the context of the X-ray provided suggest a more direct injury to the patella itself.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8489473/

choices.text: More common in males than females
HLA B27 is positive in >90% of patients

questions.text: All of the following regarding ankylosing spondylitis are true except
questions.solution:
A. Occurs before the age of 20, never after 40

  • True: While ankylosing spondylitis often presents in younger individuals, particularly males between the ages of 17 and 35, it can occur after the age of 40, although this is less common.

B. More common in males than females

  • True: AS is indeed more prevalent in males compared to females, with a male-to-female ratio of approximately 3:1 to 9:1.

C. HLA B27 is positive in >90% of patients

  • True: The presence of HLA-B27 is strongly associated with AS, and it is positive in a significant majority of patients (around 90% in some populations).

D. Non-erosive Arthritis

  • False: Ankylosing spondylitis causes Erosive arthritis.
  • All inflammatory arthritis ARE Erosive arthritis
  • Jaccoud's arthropathy - SLE + Non erosive arthritis
  • SLE is the only non-erosive arthritis

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470173/

questions.text: The most likely diagnosis from the image shown below
questions.solution:
The x ray shows bilaterally symmetrical deformity of femur multiple areas of fractures with callus formation is also seen in the femoral shaft. These findings are consistent with osteogenesis imperfecta.

It cannot be Paget's disease as it occurs in old men, but here the patient is a child as evidenced by the open physis.

It is unlikely to be fibrous dysplasia as it does not produce symmetrical deformities and also does not show fracture calluses.

It is not osteosarcoma as there is no tumour seen in the x ray.

A ground glass appearance will be seen if a large amount of woven bone produced replaces normal cortical bone.

questions.text: A fracture at which of the following sites can result in the 'Regimental badge' sign?
questions.solution:
Fracture Site Causing "Regimental Badge" Sign

A fracture at Site A, the surgical neck of the humerus, can result in the "Regimental badge" sign.

The "Regimental badge" sign refers to a loss of sensation over the skin covering the lower part of the deltoid muscle, which is innervated by the axillary nerve. This area is also known as the "regimental badge area" due to its location on the shoulder, where military badges are often worn.

The axillary nerve wraps around the surgical neck of the humerus (Site A) before supplying the deltoid and teres minor muscles. A fracture at this location can directly injure the axillary nerve, leading to paralysis of the deltoid muscle and sensory loss over the regimental badge area.

The other fracture sites are less likely to cause this specific sign:

Site B is the mid-shaft of the humerus, where a fracture can injure the radial nerve, leading to wrist drop, but not the axillary nerve.

Site C is the distal humerus, where a supracondylar fracture can injure the median, ulnar, or radial nerves, but not the axillary nerve.

Site D is the proximal humerus, where a fracture may occur through the anatomical neck or greater tuberosity, but these locations are less likely to directly injure the axillary nerve compared to the surgical neck.

Therefore, among the options provided, a fracture at Site A, the surgical neck of the humerus, is the most likely to cause the "Regimental badge" sign due to axillary nerve injury.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6952870/

questions.text: Identify the cast shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Patellar Tendon Bearing Cast

The cast shown in the image is a Patellar Tendon Bearing (PTB) cast.

The PTB cast is a type of below-knee cast that extends from just below the knee to the toes. It is designed to distribute weight-bearing forces through the patellar tendon and tibial tuberosity, rather than directly on the distal tibia. This helps to prevent skin breakdown and allows for early weight-bearing in certain lower extremity injuries or conditions.

Key features of a PTB cast include:

Extending from just below the knee to the toes

Incorporating a window over the patellar tendon and tibial tuberosity

Allowing for weight-bearing through the patellar tendon

The other options can be ruled out as follows:

A. Below knee cast is a more general term that encompasses various types of casts from the knee to the toes, without the specific PTB design.

B. Above knee cast extends from the groin to the toes and is not applicable here.

C. Cylinder cast is a type of long leg cast that immobilizes the knee in extension, which is different from the PTB cast.

Therefore, based on the characteristic features visible in the image, the cast shown is a Patellar Tendon Bearing (PTB) cast.

choices.text: Tenderness along course of the tendon

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Kanavel cardinal signs of flexor tenosynovitis?
questions.solution:
The answer is D. Pus pointing..

Kanavel signs are a set of four clinical signs that are used to diagnose flexor tenosynovitis, a serious infection of the tendons in the fingers. The four signs are:

  • Fusiform swelling of the finger.
  • Tenderness along the course of the tendon sheath.
  • Pain on passive extension of the finger.
  • Flexed attitude of the finger.

Pus pointing is not a part of Kanavel signs.

questions.text: Type 1 collagen are found in all except
questions.solution:
• Type I collagen is seen in the following skeletal tissues
    1. Annulus fibrosus of intervertebral disc
    2. Bone
    3. Menisci
  • Articular cartilage contain type II collagen

questions.text: Runner's fracture occurs in which of the following bones?
questions.solution:
• Runner's fracture: Stress fracture of the distal fibula.
  • Bumper fracture: A fracture of the tibial plateau.
  • Toddler's fracture: A spiral fracture of the tibial shaft seen in toddlers due to twisting injury.
  • Pott's fracture: Bimalleolar ankle fracture.
  • Cotton's fracture: Trimalleolar ankle fracture.
  • Bosworth fracture: A fracture dislocation at ankle where fibula is trapped behind tibia resulting in irreducibility of the ankle by manipulation.
  • Massonneuve's fracture: Fracture of medial malleolus with fracture proximal third fibula.
  • Pilon fracture: It is a comminuted intra articular fracture of the distal end of tibia.
  • Tillaux fracture: This is avulsion of anterior tibial margin by the anterior inferior tibiofibular ligament (Salter Harris type III injury).

questions.text: Which Salter Harris type of physeal injury does not displace the growth plate but damages it by direct compression?
questions.solution:
• There are many helpful mnemonics to help remember this classification system, and consequently, they are in order of prognosis from best to worst.

S: slipped physis (type I)

A: above physis (type II)

L: lower to physis (type III)

T: through or transverse or together physis (type IV)

ER: Erasure of the physis (type V)

Reference- https://radiopaedia.org/articles/salter-harris-classification?lang=us

questions.text: Lauge Hansen classification system is used for?
questions.solution: The Lauge-Hansen classification system is used for the classification of ankle injuries based on injury mechanisms that have predictable patterns and imaging findings. Along with the Weber classification, these systems are useful tools for describing and classifying ankle injuries.

questions.text: True about Blount disease:
questions.solution:
• BLOUNT'S DISEASE
    • Disease caused by abnormality of proximal posteromedial tibial epiphysis
    • Classically seen in African-American obese male child (first 3 years) and in west Indies
    • Presents as pathologic tibia vara (bowed legs)
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by drawing metaphyseodiaphyseal angle of Drenan, which if more than 11°, confirms the diagnosis.
  • Treatment- Generally a proximal tibial osteotomy is performed for correction of deformity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with non-radiating pain in lower back for the last 1 year. He also gives a history of recurrent redness and pain in the eyes. The X-ray image of his pelvis and both hips is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The points in favour of ankylosing spondylosis are:
    • Age of onset between 15 - 35 years.
    • Male gender
    • Red eyes indicating uveitis, which is the most common extra articular manifestation of ankylosing spondylosis.
    • X ray showing narrowing and sclerosis of sacroiliac joints

questions.text: What is the fracture shown in the picture below?
questions.solution:
• The fracture shown in the above image is an unstable burst fracture of the vertebra.
  • There is a loss of vertebral height on lateral view: anterior portion is commonly compressed more than the posterior portion of the vertebral body.
  • Bone fragment retropulsion into the spinal canal may occur. This requires Surgical intervention.
  • In a stable burst fracture, anterior and middle columns fail. There is no loss of integrity of posterior elements.

questions.text: 40-year-old male after RTA sustains a cervical spine injury. His lower limb power is greater than that of upper limb and sacral sensations are present. What type of spinal cord lesion is this?
questions.solution:
• Central Cord Syndrome This is the most common incomplete spinal cord injury(SCI) syndrome. It results from hyperextension injury in older person with pre-existing osteoarthritis of spine.
  • There is initial flaccid weakness followed by a lower motor neuron type of paralysis of the upper limbs and upper motor neuron(spastic) paralysis of the lower limbs, with preservation of bladder control and perianal sensations (sacral sparing).
  • The spinal cord is pinched between the vertebral body anteriorly and the buckled ligamentum flavum posteriorly with pressure getting concentrated around the cord area lying in vicinity of central canal.
  • Due to typical arrangement of spinal tracts(the arm fibres medially and the leg fibres laterally, the arms are more severely affected than the legs, resulting in a disproportionate motor impairment.
  • Clinical presentation depends on the site of involvement. In cervical spine involvement(most commonly affected area) patients present with quadriparesis with weakness involving the upper limbs(flaccid paralysis, due to LMN type lesion at the level of spinal injury) more than lower limbs(spastic paralysis due to UMN type lesion below the level of injury), varying degree of sensory loss below the level of spinal injury with or without bladder involvement. Prognosis is good with more than 50% patients recovering bladder/bowel function and ambulation.

questions.text: Chondroblastoma is a tumor of

A 38 year old man presented with slowly progressing swelling in the middle third of his right leg. X ray shows areas of radiolucency surrounded by sclerosis. Microscopy revealed epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis here is adamantinoma.
  • The points in favor are
    • Age of the patient is 38 years. Adamantinoma is typically is seen between 20 to 40 years.
    • The swelling is in the middle third of his right leg, which indicates that the tibial diaphysis is affected. The most common site of adamantinoma is the tibial diaphysis.
    • X ray shows areas of radiolucency surrounded by sclerosis, which is also a feature of adamantinoma.
    • Biopsy finding of epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma is also a feature of adamantinoma.

questions.text: Most common site of tuberculosis of spine is?
questions.solution:
Majority of cases reported in dorsolumbarregion(lower thoracic and upper lumbar) due to:

  • Greater extent of movement - stress zone due totransition of kyphosis to lordosis
  • Degree of weight bearing
  • Large surface area of spongy cancellous bone
  • Proximity to cisterna chyli and kidney.

In order of involvement:

Dorso lumbar → upper dorsal → Cervical → sacral → atlantoaxial

questions.text: A 24-year-old male was involved in a motorcycle crash and sustained the injury shown in Figure A. In the trauma bay it was noted that the patient could not extend his wrist. What artery runs with his injured nerve?
questions.solution:
• The patient has a Holstein-Lewis fracture or fracture of the distal one-third of the humeral shaft associated with neuropraxia of the radial nerve. The profunda brachii artery runs with the radial nerve.
  • The profunda artery and radial nerve exit the triangular interval between the long head of the triceps and the humerus and travel in the spiral groove distally.
  • The nerve crosses the spiral groove and pierces the intermuscular septa 7.5cm proximal to the elbow joint.
  • In this region, the nerve is at risk of injury during humeral shaft fractures.
  • A radial nerve palsy would present with an inability to extend the wrist, thumb and fingers.
  • The vast majority(80-90%) of radial nerve injuries in the setting of humeral shaft fractures recover with expectant management and as such radial nerve injury is not an indication for operative management.
  • Answer 2: The posterior circumflex humeral artery runs with the axillary nerve in the quadrangular space.
  • Answer 3: The scapular circumflex artery runs in the triangular space, without a major nerve.
  • Answer 4: The brachial artery runs on the medial aspect of the arm in close proximity to the ulnar and median nerves.

questions.text: Motor march is seen in:
questions.solution:
Axonotmesis:

  • PATHOLOGY - Axons broken, nerve intact
  • DEGENERATION - Proximally + distally
  • NEUROMA - Neuroma in continuity
  • PROGNOSIS - Recovery +/-, Motor march +

Neurapraxia:

  • PATHOLOGY - Physiological interruption, anatomically normal
  • DEGENERATION - Nil
  • NEUROMA - Nil
  • PROGNOSIS - Recovery complete within 6 weeks

Neurotmesis:

  • PATHOLOGY - Axons as well as nerve broken.
  • DEGENERATION - Proximally + distally
  • NEUROMA - End or side Neuroma
  • PROGNOSIS - Recovery poor

Nerve regeneration: As regeneration begins, the axonal stump from the proximal segment begins to grow distally.

  • If the endoneural tube with its contained Schwann cells is intact, the axonal sprout may readily pass along its primary course and reinnervate the end-organ. The rate of recovery of axon is 1 mm per day. The muscle nearest to the site of injury recovers first, followed by others as the nerve reinnervates muscles from proximal to distal, the so-called motor march.

questions.text: What causes Bouchard nodes?
questions.solution:
• Osteoarthritis can affect the small joints of the hand.
  • When OA affects the PIP, it forms a thickening in the joint called Bouchard's node
  • Similarly, when OA affects the DIP, it produces the Heberden node.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common extra articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
• Uveitis is not seen in RA, but in ankylosing spondylosis.
  • The eye change that we see in RA is scleritis and rarely scleromalacia perforans.

questions.text: A 35 year old female presented with joint pain and stiffness with pigment deposition in joints. She has noticed that her urine darkens in color some time after micturition. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Alkaptonuria is a rare genetic in born error of protein metabolism. It is the result of the deficiency of an enzyme (homogentisate 1, 2 dioxygenase - HGD), leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in connective tissue leading to a condition called ochronosis.
  • Clinical features include
    • General: Grey pigmentation in the ear cartilage or the sclerae, also skin discoloration. Urine turns black on standing.
    • Bone and joint: There is pigment deposition in the joints. Lumbar pain (ankylosis), arthritis leading to joint effusions, decreased joint mobility, impaired spinal, and thoracic mobility may lead to disability. There is also an increase in the prevalence of fractures secondary to osteopenia.
    • Respiratory: Decreased respiratory reserve and restrictive lung disease.
    • Cardiac: Valvular heart disease like aortic stenosis(more common), aortic regurgitation, mitral valve stenosis; cardiac arrhythmias; heart failure, and an increase in the incidence of coronary artery disease.
    • Neurological: Peripheral neuropathy, tinnitus, diplopia, and an increase in the incidence of stroke.
    • Metabolic: Increase in the incidence of renal, gallbladder, and prostatic stones.

questions.text: Housemaids knee is bursitis of
questions.solution:
Given below are the common named bursitis of the body.

  1. Prepatellar bursitis- Housemaid's knee
  2. Infrapatellar bursitis- Clergyman's knee
  3. Olecranon bursitis -Student's elbow
  4. Ischial bursitis- Weaver's bottom
  5. On lateral malleolus -Tailor's ankle
  6. On great toe- Bunion

questions.text: Most common site of stress fracture-
questions.solution: • The most common site of stress fracture is the tibia followed by the 2nd metatarsal (March fracture). As the tibia is not in the options, the next best choice is 2nd metatarsal.

questions.text: You are asked to see a 70-year-old woman with a swollen right knee that is warm and tender. You perform an arthrocentesis and observe positively birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals on polarized microscopy. The gram stain shows no organisms, and the synovial fluid culture grows no organisms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pseudogout is caused by calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals, which are positively birefringent on polarized microscopy.
  • Pseudogout most commonly affects the knee and, unlike gout, is more common in women than men. Polyarticular gout and pseudogout may mimic rheumatoid arthritis.
  • The lack of symmetry, prolonged morning stiffness, positive serologies, and systemic symptoms may help differentiate polyarticular crystal arthropathy from rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: Gunstock deformity is seen in which of the following fractures?
questions.solution:
• Most common complication in SCH fracture- malunion
  • Most common deformity occurs in SCH fracture- gun stock deformity or cubitus varus deformity
  • Deformity managed by- French osteotomy (lateral closing wedge osteotomy)

questions.text: The most common nerve involved in VIC is?
questions.solution:
• Volkmann ischemic contracture occurs as a result of ischemic injury to a limb, resulting in sensory loss, motor paralysis and flexion contractures.
  • It usually occurs if compartment syndrome is not identified timely and addressed.
  • The most common muscles involved are: FDP> FPL
  • The most common nerves involved are: Anterior interosseous N > Median N > Ulnar N
